Introduction

Constipation is characterized by infrequent, difficult, or unsatisfactory bowel movements.  It may be acute or chronic and can arise from various conditions.  Management is guided by identifying the cause, particularly if there are any alarm features (eg, weight loss, blood in stools, family history of colorectal cancer) to suggest a serious diagnosis (eg, colorectal cancer).  Whereas most forms of constipation do not cause serious complications (eg, intestinal perforation), sequelae that further contribute to patient discomfort (eg, hemorrhoids, anal fissures) are relatively common.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Normal defecation relies on appropriate colonic transit (peristalsis) coupled with effective evacuation of stool at the rectum.  Stool reaches the rectum, resulting in distension.  In response, the external anal sphincter relaxes, whereas the muscles of the abdomen and rectum contract to evacuate stool.  If any of the components of normal defecation are altered, constipation can occur.



There are 2 major types of constipation (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
):  primary and secondary.

Primary constipation



Primary constipation is characterized by the absence of an underlying organic or anatomic etiology and includes:



  • Normal-transit (functional) constipation:  Normal colonic motility but perceived difficulty with evacuation (eg, straining, sensation of incomplete emptying).
  • Slow-transit constipation:  Markedly delayed movement of stool through the colon, resulting in excessive water and electrolyte reabsorption from fecal material, making stools more difficult to pass.
  • Dyssynergic defecation:  Impaired coordination of the external anal sphincter, pelvic floor, and/or abdominal muscles during defecation, resulting in difficulty passing stools from the anal canal.


Risk factors for primary constipation include dietary (low-fiber diet, inadequate hydration), lifestyle (inactive/sedentary), and social (psychosocial stress) factors.

Secondary constipation



Secondary constipation is caused by an identifiable organic or anatomic cause, including:



  • Pharmacologic factors:  Opioids, anticholinergics, calcium channel blockers, iron supplements.
  • Neurologic disorders:  Multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, Hirschsprung disease, spina bifida, Parkinson disease.
  • Metabolic disorders:  Hypothyroidism, hypercalcemia, hypokalemia, diabetes mellitus.
  • Structural abnormalities:  Colorectal cancer/mass, stricture (eg, inflammatory bowel disease, ischemia, postsurgical status), rectocele, ovarian cancer (mass effect on colon).

Clinical presentation



Patients typically report infrequent stools, straining, hard stools, or a sensation of incomplete evacuation.  Abdominal bloating, discomfort, and anorectal pain may also occur.  The Bristol stool form scale (

figure 1
) can assist patients in characterizing their bowel movements.  A careful medication use history should also be obtained to identify potential culprit medications.



Physical examination of the abdomen is typically unremarkable, although care should be taken to evaluate for palpable abdominal masses.  External rectal examination may show sequelae of constipation such as external hemorrhoids (

figure 2
), anal fissures, and/or rectal prolapse (
figure 3
).  A digital rectal examination should be performed to assess for masses, stool impaction, occult blood, internal hemorrhoids, and abnormal rectal sphincter tone.

Alarm features



Alarm features that warrant further evaluation (eg, colonoscopy) to rule out a serious diagnosis (eg, cancer) include:



  • Blood in stools (eg, hematochezia, positive fecal occult blood testing).
  • Iron deficiency anemia.
  • Unintentional weight loss â‰¥4.5 kg (10 lb).
  • Family history of colorectal cancer or inflammatory bowel disease.
  • Rectal pain or tenesmus.
  • Recent onset without obvious cause.

Evaluation and diagnosis



The diagnosis is typically clinical and based on a thorough history and physical examination, with particular attention to the presence of alarm features.  Colonoscopy is indicated in patients with these concerning features or those age â‰¥45 who have not yet had age-appropriate colorectal cancer screening.  Furthermore, patients with severe constipation or symptoms refractory to typical treatment measures should undergo direct visualization by colonoscopy.



For patients who do not meet criteria for colonoscopy, the Rome IV criteria may be used to make the diagnosis of functional constipation (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) (with additional sets of Rome IV criteria specific for pediatric populations).

Laboratory evaluation



Laboratory testing should be obtained to identify potential organic causes of constipation.  These tests include a complete blood count to identify possible microcytic anemia, basic metabolic panel to identify hypercalcemia and diabetes mellitus, and TSH level to identify hypothyroidism.

Imaging evaluation



Imaging and more specialized testing are typically used only when symptoms are refractory to initial management.



  • Abdominal radiography:  Not typically necessary but if obtained, radiography can identify stool retained in the colon (
    image 1
    ).  Plain abdominal radiographs sometimes help identify other, more urgent causes of constipation (eg, small bowel obstruction, volvulus); however, abdominal CT scan is often preferred over plain radiographs.
  • Colonic transit studies:  Ingested radioopaque markers are monitored with serial radiographs as they travel through the colon to determine whether transit is abnormally slow.
  • Other tests of dyssynergy include anorectal manometry (catheter inserted in rectum to assess rectal motility and pressures), balloon expulsion testing (balloon filled with water inserted into the rectum, with manometry performed), and defecography (barium contrast administered rectally, with fluoroscopic imaging used when bearing down).


Depending on the clinical picture and progression, additional testing (eg, pelvic ultrasonography to exclude ovarian cancer in a postmenopausal woman with acute-onset constipation, pain, and an unrevealing colonoscopy) may be indicated.

Differential diagnosis



Primary constipation must be differentiated from several other conditions:



  • Irritable bowel syndrome with constipation (IBS-C):  Like functional constipation, IBS-C features chronic constipation symptoms, but it is characterized by recurrent abdominal pain related to defecation or changes in stool frequency/form (with a different set of Rome criteria than for functional constipation).  Pain is not typically expected in patients with normal-transit (functional) constipation.
  • Colorectal cancer:  The initial presenting symptom may be constipation due to obstructive masses, particularly with decreased-caliber (ribbon) stools.  The presence of additional alarm features is more suggestive of a malignant cause of constipation (
    figure 4
    ).  Colonoscopy with biopsy makes the definitive diagnosis.
  • Small bowel obstruction:  The onset of symptoms in small bowel obstruction is typically more acute than with primary constipation.  Patients often have refractory vomiting, obstipation, and abdominal distension with hyperactive bowel sounds on examination.
  • Volvulus:  Sigmoid and cecal volvulus both occur more frequently in patients with chronic constipation.  Severe abdominal pain can help differentiate chronic constipation and volvulus.  Abdominal radiographs or CT scans can be used to distinguish chronic constipation from sigmoid volvulus (dilated colon appearing as an inverted U-shape (
    image 2
    )) or cecal volvulus (large, dilated, closed colonic loop with a coffee-bean appearance (
    image 3
    )).

Management



In the absence of alarm features or concern for other organic causes, patients with constipation should undergo initial nonpharmacologic management with lifestyle modifications (

figure 5
):



  • Increased dietary fiber intake (20-35 g/day).
  • Hydration with >1.5 L/day of water.
  • Regular aerobic physical activity.


If symptoms do not improve, pharmacologic therapy should be tailored to the particular type/suspected etiology of constipation (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
).



  • Bulk-forming agents (psyllium, methylcellulose):  Contain fiber and are used to supplement increases in dietary fiber, thereby increasing fluid absorption into the stool.
  • Osmotic laxatives (polyethylene glycol, lactulose, magnesium citrate):  Increase intestinal water secretion via an osmotic gradient, augmenting bowel distension and promoting peristalsis.
  • Stimulant laxatives (senna, bisacodyl):  Promote intestinal fluid secretion and enteric neuron stimulation/peristalsis.  Appropriate for intermittent use/rescue therapy.
  • Prosecretory agents (linaclotide, plecanatide, lubiprostone):  Stimulate gastrointestinal chloride and fluid secretion into the gastrointestinal lumen to improve colonic transit.  Linaclotide and plecanatide act as guanylate cyclase agonists, and lubiprostone increases chloride secretion via the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator.
  • Peripherally acting mu-opioid receptor antagonists (methylnaltrexone, naloxegol):  Block mu-opioid receptor stimulation in the gastrointestinal tract that slows motility.  These medications have limited ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore can antagonize gastrointestinal opiate effects without sacrificing opiate analgesia in the CNS or precipitating symptoms of opiate withdrawal.
  • Stool softeners (docusate):  Act as a surfactant to decrease stool surface tension, allowing water and fats to enter the stool.  Limited data support efficacy.


Biofeedback may be helpful for dyssynergic defecation and for retraining of the external anal sphincter and pelvic floor muscles.  Surgical management is rarely indicated and reserved for refractory cases or those with reversible anatomic causes (eg, rectocele).

Complications



Untreated or poorly managed constipation may result in:



  • Fecal impaction.
  • Hemorrhoids.
  • Anal fissures.
  • Rectal prolapse.
  • Stercoral ulcers or colitis (ulcers or inflammation due to focal pressure necrosis from fecal material; can progress to intestinal perforation; initially managed with an aggressive bowel regimen).
  • Urinary retention and recurrent urinary tract infections (
    figure 6
    ).

Special considerations

Neonatal constipation



In general, healthy term infants' first bowel movement consists of meconium and occurs within the first 24-48 hours of life.  Delays in passage can indicate an underlying disorder of the gastrointestinal system, such as Hirschsprung disease and meconium ileus (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
).  Other considerations include anatomic obstruction (eg, volvulus, intestinal atresia) and congenital hypothyroidism.

Pediatric populations



Pediatric stooling patterns can be widely variable, particularly in the first year of life (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
).  After age â‰¥1, children should have approximately 1 stool per day.  Functional constipation is the most common cause of constipation in children, but alarm symptoms, especially poor weight gain/growth, abdominal distension, and abnormal examination, should alert to the possibility of a more serious underlying cause (
ðŸ“Š View Table: table 6
).



Risk factors for pediatric constipation include recent introduction of solids, psychosocial changes (toilet training, school entry), and excessive milk consumption.  Initial treatment focuses on age-appropriate toileting and dietary changes such as increasing hydration and fiber and limiting milk consumption to â‰¤24 oz/day.  Laxatives may be used if symptoms do not improve with dietary and lifestyle modification.

Prognosis



The prognosis depends highly on the underlying etiology.  Functional constipation often responds well to conservative and pharmacologic measures.  However, some patients, particularly those with underlying neurologic or inborn disorders, may be difficult to treat.  Patients with alarm features should be evaluated with colonoscopy to avoid delaying a potentially time-sensitive diagnosis of colorectal malignancy.

Summary



Constipation encompasses a range of disorders involving infrequent, hard stools and unsatisfactory defecation.  Evaluation includes a careful history, physical examination, and selective use of diagnostic studies to rule out underlying organic or anatomic causes, with particular attention to alarm features that suggest colorectal cancer.  Management generally begins with lifestyle modifications and laxatives, with escalation to advanced testing or additional pharmacotherapy for refractory cases.
